p.seg: Duke Ping of Jin asked Master Kuang:
Master Kuàng (politely) replied:
"What is the Way of a ruler over others like?"
The Way of the ruler over others
is to be quite pure and unassertive in action,
his main concern consists in far-reaching loving care,
and his urgent concern is to get to employ men of talent.
He widely opens his ears and eyes
in order to survey all the regions of the world.
and not to be hemmed in by one's senior officials.
It is to be all-encompassing and to take a large perspective on things,
and to stand alone in lofty independance.
It is again and again to reflect and to examine the performances achieved
and in this way to deal with one's ministers and subordinates.
These are the proper measures and practices of a ruler of men."
Duke Ping said:
"Excellent."
Duke Xuān of Qí said to Yǐn Wén:
"What is the business of a ruler over others like?"
Yǐn Wén replied:
"The business of the ruler over men
is to avoid assertive action and to show an ability to tolerate one's subjects.
When one's business is limited it is easy to follow up on,
when laws are sparse it is easy to base oneself on them,
and then one's people will not, on the basis of one's administration, fall foul of the law.
The great Way shows tolerance towards the common people
The sage takes sparse action and All under Heaven is well-governed.
In the "Documents" it says:
King Xuān said:
"On Mount Qi there is plain walking
When King Chéng enfeoffed Bó Qín as Duke of Lǔ,
he summoned him and addressed him as follows:
(Here it is:) As a matter of principle the incumbent of a high position
must needs show respect to his subjects.
and he must follow Virtue as well as admonition and remonstrance.
He definitely must open the gates for taboo-free advice,
he must quietly stay within the regulations and must calmly rely on them.
When faced with remonstrators he must not make a show of his authority
and he must not try to straighten out their proposals.
He will make a broad choice of their formulations (for consideration)
and will then opt for what is worth serious consideration.
Now if he has literacy but no military skills
he does not have what it takes to exercise authority over his subjects;
if he has military skills but no literacy
his people will stand in fearful awe of him but will not feel close to him.
When both literacy and military skills are deployed in action
then authority as well as Virtue will be fully realised.
As he fully realises authority and Virtue
his people will feel close to him and thus submit to him.
Moral purity will lead to success at the higher levels
and shrewd eloquence will be blocked at the lower levels.
When remonstrators get to come forward
then loyal effort and good faith get fostered."
great Virtue is tolerant regarding the subjects/subordinates.
Xiè Yě said:
I have repeatedly remonstrated with your lordship,
Depending on whence the wind blows the grass will bend accordingly
Therefore, as for the actions of the ruler over men, they must be taken cautious and diligent care of.
If one one plants a crooked tree,
how can one get a straight shadow from it?
WHENEVER a ruler of men DID NOT ensure his public acts WERE straight and his public pronouncements WERE respectable,
IT has never been THE case THAT HE was able to retain the good name of a thearch or a king,
or TO hand down an illustrious good name.
The Book of Changes says:
"When the gentleman lives in his place
and these are excellent,
and makes his public pronouncements
then people from more than a thousand leagues away will respond to him,
Bó Qín bowed twice, accepted the instruction and took his leave
but your lordship has not heeded my advice and has increasingly failed in his excercise of authority and of ritual conduct.
As for a ruler instructing his subjects/subordinates
he is like the wind bending the grass,
when the wind blows from the east, the grass bends towards the west,
and when the wind blows from the west, the grass bends towards the east.
and how much more will those who LIVE close by?
If, living in his PLACE,
he makes his PUBLIC pronouncements,
but these are not EXCELLENT,
then those living further than a thousand leagues away will offend against them,
and how much more will those who live closer by?
PUBLIC pronouncements come from the person and are addressed to the people,
administrative acts are effective in the vicinity but are seen from the distance.
public pronouncements and act
are the crucial devices of the gentleman.
The deployment of these devices
IS the determining factor for (the ruler's) glory or disgrace.
PUBLIC pronouncements and acts
are means by which the gentleman acts on heaven and earth,
could one fail to take cautious and diligent care with them?
When heaven and earth move, the myriad things are transformed.
The Odes say:
"Be cautious with the words you utter,
ensure the respectability of your authority and your ritual conduct,
in everything be mild and good."
This applies to the above.
Now if the ruler's careful attention is not to this but he gives himself free reins,
then, if he is not ruined, he is bound to get assassinated.
When Duke Líng heard this,
he thought Xiè Yě was making infamous pronouncements and killed him.
Later, Duke Líng was indeed assassinated by Zhēng Shū.
Duke Āi of Lǔ asked Confucius:
"I have learnt that the gentleman does not play backgammon.
Confucius replied:
"That is so."
Duke Āi continued:
"Why is it that he does not play chess?
Confucius replied:
"This is because there are two ATTACKERS in it."
Duke Āi continued:
If there are two ATTACKERS in it
WHY then does he not play chess?
Confucius replied:
"This is because THEY both practice a wicked course of action.
Duke Āi was put aback by this.
After a while
the Duke said:
"The gentleman hates the wicked ways as much as this!
Confucius answered:
"If the gentleman could not hate the the wicked ways intensely,
then his love for the good ways would likewise not be able to be intense.
But if in his love for the good ways he cannot be intense,
then the people's fondness for him could likewise not be intense.
The Odes have it:
"Before I see the gentleman
my worried heart is all upset,
and yet as soon as I can see him
as soon as I can contact him
It is up to this level of intensity that the Odes are fond of the good ways.
Duke Āi said:
"Excellent!
I have learnt that the gentleman brings to perfection what is admirable in men,
and he does not bring to perfection what is wicked in men.
If it had not been for Confucius,
how could I have got to learn these words?
King Xiàn of Héjiān said:
Yáo was concerned with All under Heaven
He felt pain regarding the injustice suffered by so many people,
and he worried that all manner of creatures did not flourish.
Therefore when there was just one commoner who was hungry
he would say:
"This one I have caused to go hungry."
And if there was just one person who was cold,
he would say:
"This one I have caused to be cold.
If there was just one commoner who committed a crime,
he would say:
"This one I have trapped in crime."
Kind-heartedness was shining and righteousness was established,
Virtue was spread abroad and caused widespread transformations.
And so without him handing out rewards the people felt encouraged,
without him meting out punishments the people were well-governed.
He was forbearing first, and thereafter proceded to being instructive.
Such was the Way of Yáo.
In the times of Shùn
the Yǒu Miáo refused to submit.
The reason why they did not submit
was that the Great Mountain was in THEIR south
and Mount Dian in THEIR north,
that on their left there were the waters of Lake Dongting
and on THEIR right there was River Pénglì.
They made use of these inaccessible territories,
and this was the reason why they did not submit.
Yǔ wanted to launch a formal attack against them but Shùn refused,
saying:
"My explanations and instructions are still not finished."
He went through with his explanations and instructions to them,
and the Yǒu Miáo begged to offer their submission.
When everyone learnt about this,
they all criticised Yǔ's policy of righteousness
and they rallied to Shùn's policy of virtuous generosity.
When the Duke of Zhōu ascended to the position of the Son of Heaven,
he spread his generous virtue and gave of his munificence,
The Twelve Shepherds
and the Three Locals
left on a mission to conduct a census of the peoples in the distant parts.
If there were any who were hungry and cold and did not get clothes or food
if there were any who because of lawsuits lost their business,
if there were any of talent who did not gain advancement,
they went in and made reports on it to the Son of Heaven.
The Son of Heaven, on the occasion of the rulers of those parts coming to court,
bowed to them and asked them to come forward
saying:
"Could it be that that my administration and education policy are wanting in any respect?
How is it that among the peoples they went to there are those who go hungry and cold and are unable to find clothes or food?
That there are those who because of litigation lost their business,
and that there are men of talent who do not get official advancement?"
These rulers, when they returned to their countries,
summoned their dignitaries and announced they would put into practice the words of the Son of Heaven.
When their peoples heard this,
they were all delighted and said:
"This is indeed a Son of Heaven!
How can he live so far away and see us so clearly?
How can one deceive such a man!"
Thus the Shepherds were the reason the Four Gates were thrown open,
their clear perception reached to all the four directions,
and they rached the Four Intelligences.
As a result those close to them gave them warm support
and those far way acquiesced in their rule.
In the Odes it says:
"Be mild to those far away and helpful to those close by
so as to firmly establish our king."
King Xiàn of Héjiān said:
"Yǔ said that if the people have nothing to eat
then I cannot employ them in public works;
when the completion of tasks is of no benefit to others
then I cannot urge them to undertake them.
And so he diverted the Yellow river to guide it along
and he dredged the Yangzi so it connected with the nine tributaries,
he connected the Five Lakes and firmed up the Eastern Sea.
The people surely were toiling hard!
And the reason why nonetheless they did not resent the hardship they suffered
When Yǔ left his palace he caught sight of a criminal.
He got down from his carriage, asked how he was doing and shed tears for him.
His entourage said:
"Now a criminal has not followed the proper Way
so therefore he got himself into this predicament.
Why does your lordship feel pain for him to such a degree?"
Yǔ said:
"The men under Yáo and Shùn
all made the attitude towards life of Yáo and Shùn their own.
Now I must be said to function as their ruler,
but the people each have their own mindsets.
That is why I feel pain on their behalf.
In the Documents it says:
"When the people become guilty of crimes
the fault is all in me, THEIR KING."
The Yú and the Ruì were confirming their peace with hostages to King Wén.
When they entered King Wén's borders,
they noticed how the common people yielded politely to officers and dignitaries.
And when they entered his capital,
they noticed how the officers and dignitaries YIELDED POLITELY to senior members of the government.
The two countries said to each other:
"Their common people yield politely to officers and dignitaries,
their officers and dignitaries yield politely to senior members of governent.
So then their ruler will likewise be yielding with his All under Heaven and will not be possessive about it."
The two countries,
before they had even seen King Wén in person,
went ahead and yielded the territory they were fighting over.
They considered that land idle fields and returned home.
Confucius said:
"Great indeed
was the Way of King Wén!
There is nothing one can add to it.
Without moving he achieved transformations,
and without assertive action he achieved success.
Diligent and careful he was, and politely respectful towards himself, and the Yú and the Ruì made peace all of themselves."
Therefore in the Documents it says:
"It was all a matter of King Wén's diligence and avoidance of taboos."
this applies to the above.
King Chéng was relaxing together with Táng Shūyú,
and he cut out Wutong tree leaves to make scepters of them and gave them to Táng Shūyú
and said:
"Hereby I enfeoff you."
Táng Shūyú was delighted
and told the Duke of Zhōu about this.
The Duke of Zhōu personally inquired of King Chéng about this:
"Did the Son of Heaven enfeoff Yú?"
Duke Chéng said:
"I was just joking with Yú."
The Duke of Zhū (politely!) replied:
"I have learnt
that the Son of Heaven never speaks in jest.
When the Son of Heaven speaks, then the SCRIBE records this,
the attendants recite it
and the officers quote it."
And thereupon he did indeed enfeoff Táng Shūyú in Jìn.
The Duke of Zhōu may be said to HAVE BEEN eloquent.
He gave one quotation, and (the young) King Chéng gave greater weight to his words,
he made the righteousness of showing loving care of one's younger brother [Táng Shūyú was both the Duke of Zhou's and King Cheng's younger brother.],
and he supported the solid base of the King's family.
In the times of Yáo
Shùn was the Director of Multitudes,
Xiè served as Marshal,
Yǔ served as Director of Works
Hòu Jì was the Director of Harvests,
Kuí served as Director of Music,
Chuí was Chief of Craftsmen
Bó Yí served as Clan Director,
Gāo Yáo served as Chief of Punishments,
and Yì organised the hunting expeditions.
As for Yào's physical strength and skillfulness,
he was not in a position to perform one of these functions.
Yáo held the position of a ruler, and the Nine Masters served as ministers:
Why was that?
Yáo understood that as for the responsibilities in these nine official departments,
if he ordered the Nine Masters each to undertake their tasks,
they would all be able to manage their responsibilities
so as to complete nine tasks.
Yáo then in fact did go on to complete HIS tasks so as to rule as king over All under Heaven.
Thus, IDENTIFYING [CAPABLE] men
is the Way of the ruler.
identifying official tasks
is the way of a minister.
When the ruler makes it his Way to IDENTIFY [CAPABLE] men,
and the ministers make it their Way to take charge official tasks,
and when all these take care not to pervert the models of antiquity
Tāng asked Yī Yǐn:
"The Three Dukes, the Nine Senior Ministers, the Twenty-seven Dignitaries, and the Eighty-One Basic Officers
is there a Way of understanding what they are all about?"
Yī Yǐn replied:
"In ancient times only when Yáo set eyes on anyone he understood him,
only after Shùn employed anyone did he understand him,
and Yǔ promoted people on the basis of their completing projects.
Now as for these three leaders' appointment of men of worth,
they all used different ways but completed their undertakings [CS: they all succeeded by pursuing different ways],
but they still had things they got wrong.
How much more would those get things wrong who have no methodology [CS: who has no norms and criteria!] and rely entirely on themselves!
Employing people on straightforward intuition
one is bound to fail on a grand scale.
Therefore when the ruler gets the ministers to offer up their own talents as tribute
May our descendants take good care of this."
"This is excellent."
Now, only if a true king finds men of worth and talent to serve as aides to him,
only then will there be good order.
Even if he has the intelligence of a Yáo or a Shùn, but aides are not on hand,
then the ruler's generosity will not spread everywhere
and the benefits of his education will not be put into practice.
It is therefore that the intelligent ruler in charge
takes great care in selecting his officers
and makes it his business to seek out men of worth and talent.
He establishes his Four Aides to help him
and he will have heroic men to administer the offices of state.
He ensures the honour of their ranks
and makes sure their emoluments are substantial.
The men of worth advance to show up their glory,
and the lesser talents are reticent but make their strong efforts.
Thus the person in charge has nothing left to worry about,
and those below him no wicked hidden designs.
All the officials are able to impose good order,
and the ministers and subordinates enjoy the performance of their duties.
The ruler's generosity is spread out across all living creatures,
his munificence enriches all manners of plants and trees.
In ancient times Shùn had Yǔ on his left and Gāo Yāo on his right,
and without him ever descending from his hall the All under Heaven was well governed.
This is due to the effectiveness of employing men of talent.
King Wǔ asked Tàigōng:
"Having raised worthy men of talent to office to end up in danger and being ruined,
how is that possible?
Tàigōng said:
When the King of Wú was about to attack Chǔ
he announced to his attending officials:
"Those who who have the audacity to remonstrate against will suffer the death penalty."
Among his followers there was a certain Shào Rúzǐ
who would have wanted to remonstrate against this but did not dare,
and so with pellets in his armed he wielded his slings
and in that way roamed the Park.
The dew was wetting his clothes,
but in this fashion he went on for three mornings in a row.
The King of Wú said:
"You come over here!
Why is it that you are suffering the dew to wetten your clothes like this?"
The man politely replied:
"In the Park there is a tree,
and on top of it there is a cicada.
The cicada sits on high, sings her sad songs and drinks the dew.
Little does she know that a praying mantis is right behind her.
The praying mantis crouches and wriggles closer, wanting to catch the cicada,
but little does she know that there is a yellow sparrow right next to it,
and that yellow sparrow is craning its neck, wanting to hack at the praying mantis, but little did she know that the slingshot pellets were down below.
All these three were preoccupied by their desire to obtain the profit in front oft their eyes but they never turned round to see that behind their backs disaster was waiting."
The King of Wu said:
"OK!"
And then he rested his troops (and did not in fact attack the other state).
[omit 行?] I am seventy years old
and I wish to study, but I fear it is already the dusk of my life."
Master Kuàng said:
"If it is the dusk,
why don't you hold up a candle?
Duke Ping said:
"How can it be that a mere servant pokes fun at his ruler?"
Master Kuàng said:
"How would I, as your blind servant, have the audacity to mock my ruler?
I have learnt:
When at a young age one shows fondness of study,
one is like the sun at dawn;
when as an adult one shows fondness of study
one is like the midday sun;
when as an old man one shows fondness of study,
it is like the brightness of a candle that is held up;
but if as an old age one does not devote oneself to study
one is like some walking in the dark of the night.
Would you prefer brightness of a candle that is held up
or would you prefer to walk in the dark?"
Duke Píng said:
"OK!"
One who properly understands fate will not resent Heaven (which is the source of 命：天命),
one who properly understands himself (with his deficiencies) will not resent others.
Disaster arises from "wanting to get",
and good fortune arises from "restraining oneself".
The superior man has a whole life's worth of worries,
When the Way no longer prevails in the world, only then morality arises therefrom;
when the states are not well-governed, only then filial sons arise in them;
When the Way is being opposed and opportunities are reversed, only then intrigues (or: strategies) arise therefrom.
when competition between the people are not properly sorted out, only then loving generosity arises therefrom;
16.18 Those of all kinds of creatures who manage to find their basic nature, will thrive;
those human actions who achieve the appropriate Way, will succeed.
Wherever the Way exists (or: As for such a one, in whom the Way dwells,)
everyone will rally to it (or: him);
Wherever Virtue exists
everyone prizes it;
wherever kind-heartedness exists
everyone loves it;
everyone stands in awe of it.
wherever righteousness exists
When a house leaks the people the leave it;
when water is shallow fish will avoid it;
when trees are high birds will settle on them
when largess is rich gentlemen will hurry towards it;
when there is ritual propriety the people will stand in awe of it;
and when there is devoted effort and good faith the gentlemen will die for it.
Even if one's clothes may be tattered
one's actions must be cultivated;
even if one's hair may be in disarray
Duke (posthumous title, he was merely a 侯) was going to serve wine to his senior ministers
and the date of the party was set for noon.
Guǎn Zhòng arrive late
and Duke Huan lifted a beaker to drink to him,
but Guan Zhòng poured away half of the wine.
Duke Huan said:
"Being late for settled time
and when drunk to pouring away the wine,
how can this be acceptable in relation to ritual?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
"I have been told that when the wine goes into the mouth the tongue comes out,
and when the tongue comes out speech makes mistakes;
when speech makes mistakes one's person is dismissed.
Your humble servant reckons that instead of discarding wine
it is better to discard some wine."
Duke Huán laughed and said:
"Old friend Zhòng, please rise
and take up your place of honour."
Master Zēng was working the fields wearing tattered clothes
and to say:
Please repair your clothes with these provenues.
Master Zēng did not accept the gift,
The emissary returned but went along another time
The emissary said:
It is not as if you have made a demand for this to someone else,
Master Zēng said
I am told
he who accepts presents from others is afraid of these,
and he who gives things to others shows arrogance to them.
Although you have something to confer on me
and you are not arrogant towards me,
how can I fail to stand in fearful awe of you?"
To the very end he did not accept the donation.
Shēn's (i.e. Zēngzǐ's) words
are sufficient to provide a complete explanation of his decency.
Chén is bound to be ruined!
Is that so?"
"Appointing the worthy but not using their advice,
this is to have the reputation of appointing the worthy but not obtaining the service of the reality of a true worthy [C.S.: ... but to not obtain the service of a true worthy in reality].
King Wǔ said:
"Wherein lies the mistake?"
Tàigōng said:
"The mistake is in the ruler tending to make use of minor good features only [C.S.: The mistake is in the ruler tending to make use of worthies of minor excellence only]
and not obtaining the service of true worthies."
King Wǔ said:
"What is the tending to make use of minor good features all about?" [CS: What is the tending to make use of worthies of minor excellence all about?]
Tàigōng said:
"You love to listen to praise and you fail to hate flattery;
you treat those who are not worthies as worthy,
you treat those who are not excellent as excellent,
you treat those who are in no way making devoted efforts as devoted,
and you treat those who are in no way faithful as faithful.
As their ruler [C.S.: Such a ruler] treats adulatory praise as a meritorious achievement
and devastating criticism as a criminal offense.
Those who have meritorious achievements do not get rewarded,
those who have committed crimes are not punished;
those who are given to forming multifarious factions are promoted,
and those who care little for forming factions are demoted.
As a result all the ministers form factions and hide people's talent and worth,
all the officials gang up in all sorts of factions and many of them become treacherous;
devoted ministers die because of slander, for no crimes [C.S.: in a state of innocence]
wicked ministers are rewarded for their flattery, without any meritorious achievements to their credit.
[C.S.: With such a ruler, the state will be found ....] [When 其君 is like that...] The state will then be found in the predicament first of danger and then of ruin.
King Wǔ said:
"All right!
I have today come to understand the essence of criticism and flattering praise."
King Wǔ asked Tàigōng:
"When one manages to find worthies and one shows proper respect to gentlemen (in one's realm),
in some cases one is unable to produce good governance by the use of them:
Why is that?"
Tàigōng replied:
"When one is unable to make independent judgements
and makes one's judgements on the basis of other people's speech [CS: on the basis of what other people say],
that spells disaster."
King Wǔ said:
What is it to make one's judgements on the basis of other people's speech [CS: on the basis of what other people say]?"
Tàigōng replied:
"When one is unable to settle what to decide against [CS: what to reject]
and decides against it [CS: rejects it] on the basis of other people's speech [CS: on the basis of what other people say],
when one is unable to decide on what to opt for
and one opts for it on the basis of what other people say,
when one is unable to decide what to work for [CS: to decide how to proceed]
and one decides to work towards it [CS: and one decides to proceed] on the basis of what others say,
when one is unable to decide what to punish
and one punishes things [CS: and one metes out punishments] on the basis of what other people say,
when one is unable to decide what to reward
and one rewards things [CS: and one offers rewards] on the basis of what other people say,
then the worthies will not invariably get employed
the useless people will not invariably get demoted,
and the gentlemen of the land are not invariably shown proper respect."
King Wǔ said:
All right!
[CS: How then does one govern a state?] What then is the right way of governing a state?"
Tàigōng replied:
"When one by nature dislikes to learn about the real facts
but enjoys hearing about the facts as others have them,
when one hates learning about one's own bad sides
and enjoys hearing about other people's bad sides:
These are the reasons why there is not necessarily good governance."
King Wǔ said:
"Very good!"
Duke Huán of Qí asked Níng Qī:
[for 筦 read 管] "Now Guǎnzǐ is already old.
[CS: Since he may well abandon me in this world and go on to die before me, ...] in order to abandon me in this world he may go on to die (before me)!
[CS: I am afraid that (once he is dead) the laws will not be implemented] I am afraid that the laws are not being implemented,
many people are failing [will fail] to perform their official duties,
the leading families are [will be] resentful,
and the state is [will be] full of robbers and thieves of all kinds.
How am I to ensure that treachery does not arise
and that the common people have enough to wear and to eat?"
Níng Qī replied:
"The crux is in getting to employ worthy men and then relying on these."
Duke Huán said:
"How does one get to employ worthy men?"
Níng Qī replied:
"If you open paths for them,
if you employ them after examinating them,
if you appoint them to distinguished positions,
if you provide substantial salaries for them,
if you publicise their fame,
then the gentlemen from all over the world
will itch to set out and will reach out for you [CS: come forward]."
Duke Huán said:
"I have already raised worthy gentlemen to high office and used their advice,
but except for you who have luckily come along
there have never been any commoners or remarkable gentlemen
who have directed their steps to my gates and asked for an audience with me."
Níng Qī answered;
"This is because you, my lord, have not examined them intelligently
because you have not appointed them with proper publicity
and have used their advice with doubtful hesitation,
because the offices you have given them are lowly
and because their emoluments are slight.
Moreover, as for the reasons why a state does not manage to obtain gentlemen for employment, there are five impediments to this:
that the ruler is not fond of gentlemen
and that there are sycophants by his side
is one impediment;
that those who speak up on relevant matters never have their advice used
is the second impediment;
that people are blocked out and hemmed in
and always have to rely on cronies before they can gain an audience and conduct any investigations [CS: ... before they get examined]
is the third impediment;
that in investigating criminal conduct they in questioning must come up with elaborate formulations
and in using the law are excessive,
that is the fourth impediment;
and that those who have responsibilities do as they please,
hijack the state and and issue unauthorised formal commands,
that is the fifth impediment.
Once you remove these five impediments,
then the heroes will surge up all at the same time
and the worthies and the men of wisdom will come to stay.
If these five impediments are not removed,
then on the one hand one will be in the dark on the real situation of officials as well as of the common people,
and on the other hand one will block the road for gentlemen of worth.
Therefore, as for the government of an enlightened king and a sage ruler,
it is like the Yangzi and the sea, receptive of all,
and therefore will grow to become the lord over all the rivers there are.
The enlightened king and sage ruler is open to everyone,
and therefore he will be secure and joyful, and he will last forever.
Seen from this perspective
it is not just one gentleman who makes the ruler secure and profits others."
Duke Huán said:
"Excellent!
[CS: I shall have those Five Impediments committed to writing and ...] I shall write up those Five Impediments and make them the basis of a warning."
Some time ago our former Ruler Duke Huán was physically in weak shape
and he was unable to take responsibility for pronouncements and orders,
so Xián Péng was in attendance to assist (in these matters).
His senior advisors made many mistakes,

The art of being someone else's minister is this:
one follows the other (the ruler) and obeys his commands,
in nothing one presumes to act on one's own authority;
with regard to one's duty one does not comply with it for reasons of convenience,
with regard to high rank one does not honour it for reasons of convenience.
Invariably one will work towards advancement for the state,
invariably one will work towards the support for the ruler.
As a result one's person will be held in high regard and one's children and grandchildren will retain this high regard.
And so in the administrative acts of the minister there are six kinds of correct conduct and six kinds of incorrect conduct.
When one performs the six correct kinds of conduct one will gain glory,
and when one commits the six incorrect kinds one will suffer disgrace.
Now as for glory and disgrace,
these are the gates through which disaster and good fortune arrive.
What then does one call the "six kinds of correct acts" and the "six kinds of incorrect acts"?
The six kinds of correct conduct are as follows:
The first is (for the minister), before even the first signs of something are yet showing up,
before open manifestations and omens are yet in evidence,
then clearly and independently to diagnose the critical life-threatening constellations
and the important point for success and failure (to handle them),
in good time to put a stop to things before they fully happen,
to ensure that the ruler remains above the brawl and is firmly established in a position of public glory
so that all pledge their "filial" devotion to him.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a sagely minister.
The second is to have a receptive attitude and an unpreoccupied mind,
to promote what is good and to open a path for the Way,
to encourage the ruler through ritual propriety and rectitude,
to instruct the ruler with long-term strategic considerations,
to go along with what is admirable (in his ruler),
and to save him from what does not look good;
when the project is completed and the task achieved,
then to attribute what went well to the ruler,
and never to presume independently to show off one's own efforts.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a competent minister.
The third is to be humble about one's person and to count one's own body for little,
to rise early and go to sleep late,
to promote worthy candidates, tirelessly,
frequently to make reference to concrete historical precedents of antiquity
in order to give authority to the ruler's ideas,
to do well and be beneficial,
so as to ensure the safety of the state, the symbols of the state and the ancestral temples.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a loyal minister.
The fourth is to make perspicacious investigations into what is (still) obscure,
to (fore)see success and failure,
to take early countermeasures and to save situations,
to provide leadership and be predictable,
to stop loopholes
and to stop sources of trouble,
to turn disasters into matters of good fortune
and to ensure that the ruler is without worries to the end of his life.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a wise minister.
The fifth is to guard proper form and to support the rule of law,
to delegate things to the appropriate offices and to delegate tasks as official duties,
to decline emoluments and to refuse gifts,
to refuse minor gifts of all kinds,
to dress up formally and neatly,
and to drink and eat with moderation.
If one's conduct is like this, one is an impeccable minister.
The sixth is, when the state is in disarray,
in what one does, not to engage in flattery [according to Xiang Zonglu, Shuoyuan jiaozheng, p. 35, 諫 is a mistake for 諛]
and thus to have the courage to offend the severe face put on by the ruler
and face-to-face to speak up on the ruler's mistakes,
while not refusing to be punished for one's actions,
to be prepared to die for the security of the state
and not to regret the official actions one has taken.
If one's conduct is like this, one is an outspoken minister.
These are the six kinds of correct official conduct.
The six kinds of incorrect conduct are as follows:
The first is to make oneself comfortable in one's office and to seek emoluments,
to be busy with one's personal family
and not to be preoccupied with public business;
to keep one's wisdom to oneself
and to hide away one's capabilities;
when one's ruler is hungry after political analysis
and thirsty for strategic advice,
still not to be willing to do one's best for him,
all opportunistic, to sink and float with the public opinion, up and down,
and to look for approval left and right.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a perfunctory minister.
The second is to declare excellent everything that one's ruler says
and to declare appropriate everything that one's ruler does,
secretly to seek out what it is that the ruler prefers and then to propose it
in order to pander to the ears and eyes of one's ruler,
to fall in with the ruler surreptitiously, to put up with him thoughtlessly
and to serve up pleasure for one's ruler
with no regard for the long-term harm.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a sycophantic minister.
he will not fail once in ten thousand times.
The third is to be inwardly wayward
while being outwardly pedantic,
to have crafty rhetoric and a glib face
while at the same time being jealous of real worth,
to bring out what is admirable in what one wants to promote and to hide what looks ugly therein,
to bring out the mistakes in what one wants to discourage and to hide what is admirable in it,
to make the ruler to take reckless action and to wrongly confer responsibilities
so that rewards and punishments are not correct
and orders and commands are not implemented.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a treacherous minister.
The fourth is to be clever enough to cover up what is wrong
How does a true king select his worthies?
and eloquent enough to put rumours into circulation,
to twist words and turn round phrases to produce literary works,
at home to be at odds with one's close relatives
and in public to create chaos at court.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a double-faced minister.
The fifth is to monopolise authority and to arrogate power,
to take over affairs of state and to play the adjudicator of economic affairs,
with one's personal clan to create factions so as to enrich one's family
and so as in addition to increase one's authoritative position of power,
to illegally amend the ruler's commands so as to make oneself appear noble and illustrious.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a bandit minister.
The sixth is to flatter the ruler so as to make him evil,
to make the ruler descend into unrighteousness,
to make factions and gang up in gangs
in order to keep the ruler in the dark,
inside to be all clever talk and beautiful diction
but outside in the world to present an entirely different story,
to ensure that there is no distinction between moral black and white,
that there is no difference between right and wrong,
to be on the look-out for any chance to shift responsibility
to cause the ugly sides of the ruler to be broadcast throughout the land
and to be heard of among all the neighbouring states.
If one's conduct is like this, one is a minister in a doomed state.
This is what we call the six kinds of incorrect conduct.
The worthy minister will keep on the Way of the six kinds of correct conduct
and will not practice the art of the six kinds of incorrect conduct.
As a result, the rulership will be safe, and its subjects will be well-governed.
In life to be exposed to joy,

This, then, is the art of being someone else's minister.

Tāng asked Yī Yǐn:
"What is the difference between the Three Paramount Aides, the Nine Chief Ministers, the Dignitaries, and the Gentlemen at Court?"
Yī Yǐn replied:
"As for the Three Paramount Aides,
they are the kind whose knowledge reaches right unto the Great Way,
whose responses to changes/emergencies are unlimited,
who discourse on the essence of the myriad kinds of things
Their pronouncements are so powerful as to steer Yin and Yang
and intellectually reach right unto the Way of Heaven.
and to set aright the four seasons.
They moderate the thunderstorms,
and, being of this kind,
they are being put forward as the Three Paramount Aides.
Thus it is that the official tasks of the Three Paramount Aides
invariably reside in the Way itself (at the most elevated level).
As for the Nine Chief Ministers,
they do not interfere with the four seasons,
they interconnect the irrigation canals,
they keep the dykes in good shape,
they plant trees,
and see to the high quality of the five kinds of grain.
They are the ones who know all about territories and domains. [地里 perhaps to be taken for 地理 as in many later editions.]
They are capable of reaching what others cannot reach,
and they are able to derive profit from what others cannot profit from.
Those who are like this
one raises to office and appoints as the Nine Chief Ministers.
And so the tasks of the Nine Chief Ministers
invariably reside in matters of (superior) Virtue.
As for the Dignitaries,
both in public and at home they share the joys of the people,
in their positive and negative choices they share their interest with the people.
They have a thorough understanding of the affairs of others,
but in their administrative acts they keep to the ink-line of proper procedure.
They will not feel hurt by other people's words,
and they will speak their minds to the world at large
without thereby harming their own persons.
They ensure proper passage through passes and bridges
and they fill the storehouses and arsenals of the state.
Those who are like this
one raises to office and appoint them as Dignitaries.
And so the tasks of the dignitary
invariably reside in human-heartedness.
As for the Gentlemen at Court,
they understand righteousness and never fail to live up to this their attitude.
When a task is successfully performed, they do not alone monopolise the rewards for this,
they are devoted to correctness, and they remonstrate strongly, without any treacherous cheating.
They eschew personal profit and establish public benefit, and in their pronouncements they observe the norms of legal administrative procedure.
Those who are like this
one raises to office and one appoints them as Gentlemen at Court.
And so the tasks of the Gentlemen at Court
invariably reside in righteousness.
Thus when the Way, (superior) Virtue, human-heartedness and righteousness are firmly established, then the realm is in the right shape.
Quite generally, these four kinds of men
are the ministers of an enlightened king, but he does not call them ministers."

The Nine Chief Ministers

The Dignitaries

and such a constellation is called the hierarchic division of official tasks.

Marquis Wén of Wèi was about to appoint a prime minister.
He summoned Lǐ Kè in order to consult him on the matter,
and said:
"I am about to appoint a new prime minister.
I will choose between Jì Chéngzi and Zhái Chù for the appointment,
whom should I appoint?"
Lǐ Kè said:
"I am told
that the plebeians do not advise the noble,
that the outsider does not advise the insider,
that the isolated does not advise the intimate.
Now as for my humble self, I am isolated and plebeian.
I will not presume to do as I am being told."
Marquis Wén said:
"This is a matter of state.
I hope to consider this thing together with you, Sir, and that you will not refuse."
Lǐ Kè said:
"That you, my Lord, have not examined the background of this
is evident.
In the case of a noble person one looks whom he promotes;
in the case of a rich person one looks to see with whom he collaborates;
in the case of a poor person one looks to see what choices he will not make;
in the case of a destitute person one looks to see how far he will not go.
If you look at the matter from this angle,
it is evident."
Marquis Wén said:
"You may withdraw!
My prime minister has been decided on."
Lǐ Kè withdrew
and ran into Zhái Huáng.
Zhái Huáng asked:

in the case of a rich person one observes with whom he cooperates;
in the case of a poor person one observes what choices he will not make;
in the case of a destitute person one observes how far he will not go.

the case is clear.'

Thus when the scholar desires to establish righteousness and to practise the Way

without taking into consideration benefit or harm before he is capable bringing things to fruition.

Unless someone is an excellent cultivated true gentleman

Prince Bǐ Gān had himself killed in order to realise completely his loyal devotion,

Bó Yí and Shū Qí caused themselves to die in order to completely realise their moral purity.
These four maters
are all the most courageous (for 通 read 勇) of men:
how should they fail to be concerned for their persons?
To consider that righteousness is not established
and that one's name is not made distinguished
this is a shame to the scholar.
That is why he is prepared to cause his own death in order to realise the proper behaviour.
From this point of view
humble status and poverty

What the scholar is ashamed of

when they list up those who show moral purity and he is not one of them.
When these three qualities are present in a person

he will be side by side with sun and moon and his light will not be extinguished.
Even in ages when the Way does not prevail

And yet it is not that he loves death and hates live,

Confucius said:

when wealth can not properly be sought

This means that one does not fail to live up to oneself.

The count of beheadings per year is in the ten thousands,

The failure of the Great Peace to be realised as yet

When the emotions of men are at peace then joy arises,

While one is beating someone up

And so when a prisoner is unable to handle the pain

but when reporting to the higher authorities they are afraid of being rejected
then they touch things up and make a comprehensive submission.
Probably, by the time their relevant submission is finished
even if (the lenient) Gāoyáo head the case

Why are things like this/
Those who finalise and touch up the indictments are many
and the crimes for (unconvincing) submissions are clear.
Therefore the judicial officials concentrate on severity
and the go to every length to maltreat their culprits
and they do everything secretly
without regard to the harm they do to the state.
These are the great culprits of our age.
Therefore the popular saying has it:
"If one draws prisons on the ground
one definitely must not get in there;
if a wooden sculpture serves as an official
one definitely most not answer back to it."
All this expresses resentment against the ways of the officials
these are words of sad affliction.
Thus among the threats to the world
none is more profound than criminal litigation.
And among what ruins the law brings disorder to the administration
what disintegrates families and what obstructs the Way
nothing has a greater impact than the judicial officials.
This is what I call the one issue that still persists.
I am told that only when the eggs with fledglings are not destroyed

only when the offense of public criticism goes unpunished

Thus the Commentary says:

the rivers and marshes attract mud,

Risking death I submit

will listen to incisive remarks
open the mouths of everyone int he world
open wide the paths of remonstration,
and discontinue the one point about Qín that has been omitted,

be economic with legal administrative system
be lenient with punishments and fines

for the wind of Great Peace then to be able to rise in our times

The document was submitted,

Duke Píng of Jìn was building a tower in springtime.
Shū Xiàng said:
"This is not acceptable.
In ancient times the sage kings set high store by virtue and made it their business to be generous.
They were slow to carry out executions and they paid urgent attention to the agricultural calendar of the people.
Now to build a tower in spring,
this is to interfere with the people's agricultural calendar.
In fact, if one does not deploy one's virtuous generosity then the people will not rally to one,
and if one is not lenient in the deployment of corporal punishment the the people will be unhappy.
Deploying a people that does not rally to one
and imposing corvée labour on people who bear unhappy resentment against one
and then to go on to interfering with their agricultural calendar
this amounts to heavily exploitation.
In fact, when shepherding the people
to nourish them, but to exploit them heavily
how is that a way to ensure a safe fate for oneself, to survive in peace
and to hailed as a ruler having acted for the people among later generations?"
Duke Píng said:
"Excellent!"
And he desisted from the corvée labour for the tower.

He told his advisors:

Yǐn Duò replied:

one can put off the planting and make them concentrate on the tower.

Jiǎnzǐ got scared by the thought
so he forgot about the tower and called off the corvée labour,
saying:
I may consider the tower an urgent project
but it is not as urgent as the (welfare of) the people.
The people, because of my not building the tower
will on that basis understand my loving care for them."

Wénzǐ said:

Now have you ever found anyone happy without a territory and wanting to be rich?

Zǐyóu said:
"Yes."

when it comes to the people in Zhèng

He said:

now when someone comes along offering up a city

this would be to get things wrong with the rewards
that way, what would be attractive in this?

When Confucius went to Chǔ
there was a fisherman who offered up a very strong fish,
but Confucius would not accept it.
The man who offered up that fish said:
"It is hot and the market is a long way off,
if I offer it for sale I won't get it sold,
I was thinking about it and wanted to throw it into the dustbin
but decided it was better to offer it to a true gentleman."
Confucius bowed twice and accepted the fish.
He ordered his disciples to clean the place and was about to sacrifice the fish.
The disciples said:
"That man was about to throw it away
and now you are preparing to sacrifice it:
How is that?"
Confucius said:
"I am told
that someone who wants to be generous and does not let leftovers rot away

Now I have received a gift from a sage:
can I do other than make a sacrifice of it?"

what is it like?"
and no others are capable of destroying or injuring him;

Zhuāng Xīn replied;
when walking about he does not follow on the heels of bodyguards

The King of Chǔ went on to ask:
"When a true gentleman is rich

when he feasts others with food and drink

The King of Chǔ said:

The prime minister, Marquis of Xīpíng in Dìngguó
His father was called Yú-gōng or Master Yú
was from Dōnghǎi commandery, in the Xiàpī district.
He was a district judicial officer and then an acting magistrate.
In deciding criminal cases he was level-handed and followed the law,
and he never was unjust in any way.
Those who offended the written low in his commandery
were decided on on the basis of just procedure
and they all would never dare to conceal the real facts of a matter.
In the commandery of Dōnghǎi the established a shrine for Duke Yú in his lifetime
and they gave it the name Duke Yú Sirine.
Now in Dōnghǎi there was a filial lady
childless,
who had become a widow at a young age.
She cared for her mother-in-law very meticulously
and her mother-in-law wanted to marry her off again,
but to the end the filial lady would not go along with that.
The mother-in-law told a neighbour:
"The filial woman cares for me very meticulously
and I feel for her because she has no children and remained a single widow for so long.
I am old now.
If she could get involved with some fellow,
how about that?"
After this the old lady strangled herself
and her daughter announced to the magistrate:
"That woman has killed my mother!"
The magistrate arrested the filial lady
but the filial lady declared that she had not killed her mother-in-law.
When the magistrate wanted to pursue the matter with all the strictness of the law
the filial lady produced a false confession.
They wrapped up the case and sent it up to the Yamen.
Duke Yú considered that having cared for her mother-in-law for fifteen years and being famous for her filial piety,
this lady would not have killed her mother-in-law.
The governor did not accept this opinion
and although Duke Yú fought for the case several times he got nowhere.
At that point Duke Yú resigned on the grounds of illness and left the magistature.
The governor in the end killed the filial lady.
In the commandery there was a drought lasting three years.
And later the governor arrived
and by dinivation he sought to find out the reason.
Duke Yú said:
"It was not right that the filial lady died.
A while ago you, governor, insisted on having her killed.
The disaster is presumably due to this."
At that point the governor killed an ox and sacrificed to the tomb of the filial lady.
Everyone from the governor down attended on their own accord.
Immediately, from then on, there were great amounts of rain
and there were rich harvests.
Within the commandery people showed increasing veneration to Duke Yú.
Duke Yú built a cottage
and he told the carpenter:
"Make the gate high for me!
In dealing with criminal cases i have never passed unjust judgment.
My descendants are sure to be appointed as a marquis.
Make it have room for a high baldachin and for a four-horse team."
When it came to his son
he was appointed as Marquis of Xīpíng.

Guǎn Zhòng went out to welcome him and said:

Guǎn Zhòng said:

The third one had an elder brother who was being charged with a crime

And so it is that I got three men to come with me:
Guǎn Zhòng ascended his chariot and said:
"Fie for that!
I am bound to get into trouble.
I am incapable of blowing the spring winds over people

I'm finished!"
As a matter of principle when it comes to human nature
none of them do not wish to improve their virtue
but those who cannot improve their virtue
but profiteering defeats the purpose.
And so the true gentleman is ashamed to argue for profit or fame;
even arguing for profit and fame he is ashamed of
how much more would he be ashamed of seeking to derive profit from the position he occupies!
When the Son of Heaven of the Zhōu sent out the Family Senior to demand chariots and gold from the feudal lords
the Annals criticised him for it.
Thus, when the Son of Heaven is fond of profiteering then the feudal lords will be greedy;
when the feudal lords are greedy, then the dignitaries will be mundane;
when the dignitaries are mundane then the common people will become thieves.
The way in which superiors change their inferiors
is like the wind bending the grass.
And so a ruler of men
must fully understand to hold virtue in high esteem, to hold profit in low esteem and to lead those below,
but the evil-doing of those below
may still not be stopped,
for Duke Yǐn was greedy for profit and in person he went to fish on the River Jì
and he organised the march of the eight rows of dancers.
In this way he imposed a change on th people of the state
and how could the people of the state fail to become remiss in their duties?
Being remiss in their duties they gave free rein to their desires
disasters arose and all manner of subordinates became extravagant.
And thus it was that in the fifth year for the first time they recorded "locusts",
this means that the disasters will arise
and that the state will be misruled.
Sūn Qīng said:
"The fighter
is the one who disregards his own person
who disregards his parents,
who disregards his ruler
he acts upon the moment's anger and picks a fight.
Even facing disaster for the rest of his life
still to go on to fight
that is to disregard one's own person;
when one household will be spread in all directions
one's relatives will be killed,
then still to gon on to fight,
that is to disregard one's parents;
when it will have bad effects on the ruler
and when it is what the criminal laws strictly prohibit
and one still breaks the rules
that is to disregard one's ruler.
Now even birds and beasts know to keep close to their parents
and this is not to disregard their parents.
When a man disregards his own person
when inside he disregards his parents
and above he disregards his ruler
this is to be inferior in kind-heartedness to the birds and beasts.
As a matter of principle, the fighters
will all conider that they are right
and they will consider that the others are in the wrong.
If they themselves really are right
and others really are wrong,
then they themselves are true gentlemen and the others are petty men.
Now as a true gentleman to enter mortal conflict with petty men,
this is what people call using (precious) foxfurt to repair dog and goat fur.
it is like besmirching one's person with soot:
Surely this is excessive.
Do you consider this wise?
But nothing could be more stupid!
Do you consider this as profitable?
But nothing could be more harmful!
Do you consider this is glorious?
But nothing is ore shameful.
That among people there is fighting,
why is that?
Are we to liken them to madmen, or the sick?
But that is not right!
They are men with faces and for the most part their likes and dislikes are the same as those other men.
The fighting among men
is in truth that they are stupid, confused and oblivious of the Way."
As the Ode (255) has it:
"You shout and clamour
turn day into night."
This speaks of the actions of fighters.

Yuèyáng served as a general to Marquis Wén of Wèi

but Yuè Yáng did not lose heart for that

Mèngsūn caught a fawn alive in a hunt

Qín Xībā could not bear this
and he let the fawn free giving it back to its mother.
Mèngsūn got furious and chased Qín Xībā away.

he summoned Qín Xībā to become his son's tutor.
An adviser said:
This Qín Xībā has committed a crime against you.
Now you make him your son's tutor.
Why is that?"
Mèngsūn said:
"The man could not bear injustice against a single fawn
how then would he be able to bear injustice against my son?"

Artful fraud is not as good as fumbling honesty.
Yuè Yáng was held in suspicion because of his achievements
and Qín Xībā was considered more trustworthy because he committed a crime.
It is a matter of being kind-hearted or being callous.

Confucius said:
"Virtue is not alone,
there must be a neighbour."
Those who exercise virtuous generosity find it important not to make a show of virtue,

its front feet are those of rat,

when it gets to eat sweat herbs

The two beasts
likewise do not love the jué by nature,
it is because when it finds tasty herbs it leaves these to them
Now birds and beasts and various animals still know to borrow from each other and to repay each other's favours.
how much more should an official or a true gentlemen, when they desire to raise their fame and be of benefit to the world?

and off his own bat plans for his private household,
that the a source of disaster.

made explanations for me in term of kind-heartedness.

those who make illustrious my name
those who cause me to become a full-grown man

those who stop me on grounds of ritual propriety
those who remonstrate with me on grounds of duty of honour,
those who protect and support me

among these you are certainly at the head.

dishes and mats of all kinds he ordered his men to throw away

Otherwise,
who would dare to start the trouble.

Now what you have issued your order

At that point Duke Jǐng summoned Zhào Wǔ and Chéng Yīng to bow to all generals.

So how can one say that man can do without generosity?

On Hán Jué it may properly be said that he did not disregard generous favours he had received.

Níng (actually Nán 南) Wénzǐ had prepared three hundred rolls of silks

Dignitary Bào said:
"Although Wú is a large state
if we have not wanted to ruin the relations

then that was surely respectful already.

Níng Wénzǐ did not follow this suggestion
and he sent off the presents to him.
When Wú Chìshì arrived at the Zhì clan's place
When he had successfully completed his task
he was about to return to Wú.
The Earl of Zhì ordered boats to be built and bridges to be constructed.
Wú Chìshì said:
"I am told
when the Son of Heaven reaches a river
he has boats built and bridges constructed
that feudal lords tie together boats to make a bridge,
and that a dignitary use twin-body ships.
Using twin-body ships
is the duty of a minister.
Moreover, the respect they show me is excessive.

When he ordered someone to observe the visitor
it turned out that he was using troops hidden behind himself

Wú Chìshì said:
"Wèy has lent me right of passage
and given me abundant presents,
if I notice imminent trouble and do not avert them of these

He declared himself ill and staid where he was
and sent someone to report matters to Wèy.
The citizens of Wèy were on their alert
and when the Earl of Zhì learned about that
he desisted from his planned surprise attack.
Chǔ and Wèi held a meeting in Jìnyáng
and were planning to launch a formal attack on Qí.
The King of Qí was upset about this
and he sent someone to summon Chūnyǔ Kūn and tell him:
"Chǔ and Wèi are planning to launch a formal attack on Qí,
and I hope you as well as I are equally worried about that.
Chūnyǔ Kūn laughed out aloud and made no response.
The King asked him again,
and he again laughed out aloud and did not respond.
Three times he asked, and three times he got laughed at and got no response.
The King, furious, showed anger on his face.
"Are you, Sir, taking my state for a plaything?"
Chūnyú Kūn replied:
"I would never dare to take Your Majesty's state for a plaything.
I was laughing at my neighbour's sacrifices to his local deities.
As he is using a box with foodstuff and a carp
he would intone as follows:
"From my lowly marshy fields
may I get a hundred cartloads of grain,
and may my dry fields turn out suitable for wheat."
What I was laughing at was that what he sacrificed with was little
but what he was seeking was much."
The king said:
"Well put!"
And he gave him a thousand cash
as well as a hundred leather-protected chariots
and he established him as a Senior Minister.
When Yáng Hú fell afoul of Wèy
he turned north and visited Jiǎnzi and told him:
"From now onwards
I shall no more establish anyone in official positions.
Jiǎnzǐ said:
"Why so?"
Yáng Hú said:
"As for those in the official hall
more than half are my appointments.
Of the court officials
those that I have established
also constitute more than half.
Of the officials at the borders
those that I have appointed
are also more than half.
Now these men in the official hall
have taken a personal initiative to block my access to my ruler;
the court officials
have taken personal initiatives to put me in legal danger;
the border officials
have taken personal initatives to attack me in relation to the military."
Jiǎnzǐ said:
"Only a worthy person is capable of repaying generosity,
and the unworthy is incapable of that.
Now a person who plants a peach or a plum tree
will get to rest in summer
and will get fruit from the trees in the autumn;
but someone who plants caltrops and pigweed
will find no rest in the summer,
and in the autumn he will get the thorny harvest.
Now what you have planted
were caltrops and pigweed,
they are not peaches and plum trees.
From now onwards
you should select the people to establish
instead of having established them then to choose among them."
Dōng Lǘzǐ used to be rich and noble, but afterwards became a beggar.
Someone put a question to him
and said:
"Why have you got to this stage?"
He said:
"I know it myself. When I was prime minister for six or seven years
I never got anyone into a noble position;
when I was rich I was twice worth three million,
but I never made a single person rich.
I did not understand that my failures when having made it would cause this to become so."
Confucius said:
"How difficult things are!
Small or large, abundant or sparse
they each involve resentments and hatreds,
that is a given principle in Fate.
[for 人 read 內 向宗魯] A person may (properly) "get" things,
but outside himself he can only borrow things."
Marquis Wén of Wèi was in conversation with Tián Zǐfāng
when a pair of little boys in black and white dress were in attendance with them before the ruler.
Zǐfāng said:
"Are these your favourite children?"
Marquis Wén said:
"They are not.
Their father died in battle
and these are his young orphans.
I have taken them in."
Zǐfāng said:
"I find your heart murderous enough.
But now things are worse than that.
As you now throw your affections over these children
whose father will they go on to kill?"
Disconcerted, Marquis Wén said:
"I accept your commands."
From this time onwards
weapons and leather shields were not used (not in front of the children...)
Wú Qǐ served as a general for the state of Wèi
and he launched an attack against Zhōngshān.
Among his military forces there was someone who suffered from an abcess
and Wúzǐ sucked out the pus from it.
When the man's mother broke into tears at this
a bystander said:
"The general treating your son like this
why do you still weep?"
She replied:
"Wúzǐ has already sucked the wound of this my son's father
and led to him getting killed in the battle of the River Zhù:
before that battle had properly started my son died.
Now the general goes on to suck the abcess of this one
and how am I to tell in what battle he will die?
That is why I lament for him."
Duke Yī of Qí, when he was still a prince,
was fighting a legal battle with Bǐng Chū's father, but lost.
When he ascended the throne
he dug up the corpse of his opponent's father and amputated its foot
and he made Chū himself his valet.
He also took away Yōng Zhì's wife
and made Zhì serve as his assistant carriage keeper.
When the Duke was swimming in Lake Shēn
two people were bathing in that lake
and Chū struck Zhì with a whip.
Zhì was furious.
Chū said:
"When someone else took away your wife from you you never dared to show any anger,
but as soon as I strike you
why are you so upset?"
Zhì said:
Well then: how about not reacting when they amputate one's dead father's feet?"
And so the two plotted to kill Duke Yī
and shoved him into a bamboo copse.
The Chǔ burghers presented a tortoise to Duke Líng of Zhèng.
Prince Jiā noticed
that Prince Sòng's finger twitched
and he told Prince Jiā:
"At other times when I was like this
I was bound to taste some exquisite delicacy."
When they were serving the tortoise to the dignitaries
they called up Prince Sòng but did not give him any of it.
Prince Sòng was furious
and he dipped his finger into the tripod with the food
tasted the contents and stormed out.
The Duke in turn got furious
and wanted to have him killed.
Prince Sòng and Prince Jiā made plans to take early measures against this,
and in the end they killed Duke Ling.
Zǐxià said:
"The Annals are the text where it was noted when rulers did not properly behave as rulers
when ministers did not properly behave as ministers,
when fathers did not properly behave as fathers
and when sons did not properly behave as sons.
This is not a matter for one day or another:
there is a gradual progress required in order to reach this aim.
In administration there are three categories.
The administration of a true king
educates people;
the administration of a hegemon
overawes people;
the administration of a strongman
threatens people.
As for these three they each have something they realise
but it is the education that is the noblest of them.
If education does not change the situation, only then does one (have to) overawe people;
if overawing people does not change the situation, only then does one (have to) threaten them;
if threatening people does not change the situation, only then does one apply punishments to them.
When it gets to the stage of punishing
then that is not something the true king values highly.
Therefore the sage king will give priority to teaching based on Virtue and have punitive action as a last resort;
he will establish a sense of glory and shame but also make clear prohibitions and interdictions.
He will venerate the moderating power of ritual propriety and righteousness so as to show them up as a model,
and he will treat the decrepitude of (concern for) property and profit as vulgar so as to change them.
When one takes care with what is close at hand and sorts out what is inside,
and when one properly administers that ritual propriety which is what locks and unlocks everything,
when one evens out the relations between husband and wife
then those below one will love the glory of righteousness and ritual propriety
and will hate the shamefulness of greed and revolt.
And as for the source from which this achievement flows
it is transformation/education that makes it so.
Jìsūn asked Confucius;
"If one kills those who have not the Way
and keeps alongside those who have the Way,
how would that be?"
Confucius said:
"As you conduct the government
why should you put others to death.
If you desire the good, then the people will become good as a result.
The virtue of the true gentleman is like the wind
and the virtue of the small man is like grass.
As for grass if one blows wind over it is bound to bend."
The words here do no more than elucidating education.
In governing a state there are two mechanisms:
these are punishment and virtue.
A true king will hold virtue in high esteem and make punishments rare,
and a typical hegemon will deploy punishments and virtue alongside,
A strong state will give priority to punishements and put virtue last.
Now punishments and virtue
are the sources from which education rises.
Virtue
nourishes goodness and moves along those who lack it;
punishments
penalise wickedness and interdict recidivism.
Therefore those who revere education through virtue reap rewards
and those are punished in the extreme reap execution.
Now execution and rewards
are the means to hold apart the worthy from the unworthy,
and line up those who have merit and those who do not have merit.
That is why executions and rewards must never be misguided.
When executions and rewards are misguided then good and evil will be in disorder.
Now when if one has achievements one is not rewarded, then the good will not be encouraged;
when if one has committed an offence one is not punished then the bad will not be afraid.
As for the good not to be encouraged and the bad not to be fearful but one then being able to conduct an education of everyone
that is unheard of.
The Documents say:
"Use all one's energy on rewards and punishments."
That applies to the above.
When the water is contaminated the fish in it are in trouble
when orders are harsh the people will revolt,
when walls are high and perpendicular they are bound to collapse,
when shores are high and abrupt they are bound to fall in.
And so when it comes to governing a state it is like tuning a lute:
when the large strings are too tight the small strings will snap.
Therefore it is said:
"He who holds the reins and the horse bit tight
is not a driver who manages a thousand leagues (a day)."
The sound that consists of sound
will spread no more than a hundred leagues;
the sound that goes beyond sound
reacher all the way to the Four Seas.
Thus when salaries are not proportionate to achievements, they are reduced
when titles are not proportionate to the realities of performance they are rescinded.
When the real performance is checked and the corresponding titles are fitted to it
then the disaster (of punishment) and the good fortune (of appointment to office) will not come about out of nothing.
As the Odes have it:
"Why is he there?
There must be someone he is with;
Why is he staying long,
there must be a reason."
This applies to the above.
When Gōngshū Wénzǐ served as prime minister of Chǔ
for three years
none of the people dared to enter the court.
Gōngshū's son obtained an audience and said:

Wénzǐ said:

The son said:

and when those below are silent those above will be deaf.
When the deaf and the mute cannot communicate with each other
what proper government of the state is there to speak of?"
I'm told
that if one goes smoothly along with needle and thread one can make a curtain,
if one collects pecks and bushels of grain one can fill the storehouses.
by combining small rivers one fills streams and seas.
The enlightened ruler
will in some cases receive instruction but not act on it,
but he will never refuse to receive any such instruction."
Duke Líng of Wèy said to Confucius:
"Somebody
When the person who runs the state takes good care with it up in the temple hall
then the state wil be in good order:
