If one likes others then they will like you;
if you hate others then they will hate you.
If you know how to achieve something for yourself
then you also know how to achieve it for others.
This is what is called understanding the world without ever leaving one's walled compound.
It is to know how to be
Zǐgòng consulted Confucius on government of the people.
Confucius said:
"Be all fearful as if steering a wayward horse with a rotten rope."
Zǐgòng said:
"What is there to be afraid of?"
Confucius said:
Even a fully accomplished state consists of people
If one guides them in accordance with the Way they will be one's domestic animals
if one does not guide in accordance with the Way they will be one's enemies.
How is one to avoid being afraid?"
Duke Huán of Qí said to Guǎn Zhòng:
"I want to get things done for my state
and to be shining forth like the sun and the moon,
so that be they stupid men or stupid women, everyone will say: well done!
Is that possible?"
Guǎn Zhòng said:
That is possible.
However, it is not the Way of a sage."
Duke Huán said:
"What do you mean?"
Guǎn Zhòng replied:
With a short rope you cannot reach into a deep well. With scanty knowledge one cannot join the discourse of a sage;
with a clever scholar one can enter into disquisitions on things;
with a wise man one can enter into disquisitions of the boundless;
with a sage one can enter into disquisitions on spiritual enlightenment.
Now what the sage is trying to do
is beyong the reach of the hoi polloi.
The people may be aware that the sage is ten times superior to themselves
but still they try to compete with him
and they say:
"He is not as good as we."
If he is a hundred times as good as they
they will be upset about his failings;
if he is a thousand times as good as they
[For 誰 read 譙] they will blame him and will not trust him.
Therefore the people cannot be controlled by subtle means,
but they must be rounded up (like a flock of sheep) and shepherded;
they cannot be killed by violent means
but they may be caused to do things by being directed (by gestures of command).
The masses cannot be coaxed into doing something by going from door to door
Duke Líng of Wèy asked archivist Yóu:
"In administration who has the most important resposibilities?"
The archivist replied:
"The senior judge has the most important responsibilities.
When the administration of legal cases is not exact,
then those who have been made to die cannot be brought to life
and what has been severed cannot be put together again.
That is why I am saying
the senior judge has the most important responsibilities."
After a short while,
Zǐlù had an audience with the Duke,
and the Duke transmitted to him what archivist Yóu had said.
Zǐlù said:
"The field marshal has the most important responsibilities.
When there is a problem between two states
and the two armies are on a par
the field marshal holds the stick to beat the attack drum with and implements policies,
when he does not get things right in a single conflict
the dead will be counted in the ten thousands.
Causing the death of another is considered wrong,
and in this he causes the death of others surely in large numbers.
Therefore I say:
The field marshal has the most important responsibilities."
After a short while
Zǐgòng went in for an audience,
and the Duke told him the words of the two others.
Zǐgòng said:
"They have no idea!
In ancient times Yǔ fought a battle with the Hù.
Three times he arranged a formal assault, but they did not submit.
At that point Yǔ organised military training for one year
and the Hù begged to submit (without the need for any campaign).
Therefore it is said:
Once one removes the issues between the people
what litigations are there to adjudicate
if offensive and defensive weapons are not lined up
what drums of attack are there to sound?
Therefore I conclude:
"Military training is the most important responsibility."
Duke Huán of Qí was out on a hunt.
Pursuing a deer he ran into a deep valley
saw an old man and asked him
and said:
"What valley is this?"
He replied:
"It is the Fool's Valley."
Duke Huán said:
"Why is it called that?"
He replied:
"Because I gave it this name."
Duke Huán said:
"When I look at you appearance,
you are not a stupid man.
Why did you give it the name of that Duke."
He replied:
"Please let me explain this.
I basically raise buffaloes,
and when they have offspring and these grow to be adult
then I offer them for sale and I buy a young colt.
A young man told me:
"A buffalo cannot engender a horse."
Then he took the colt away from me.
A neighbour heard about this
and thought I was stupid.
So that is why I called this valley the Fool's Valley."
Duke Huán said:
"You are foolish indeed!
Why did you let him have the colt?"
Then Duke Huán returned home.
The next day he held court
and he told Guǎn Zhòng about his experience.
Guǎn Zhòng straightened his lapel bowed twice and said:
"It is all my stupidity:
if Yáo was at the head
Jiù Yóu was chief justice
And if anyone was exposed to such an imposition like this old man
he would, moreover, certainly not have given it away.
This man knew that judicial practice was not legally correct
and therefore he gave away the colt.
I beg to withdraw and to adjust the administration."
Confucius said:
"You, my disciples, remember this:
Duke Huán
was a hegemon ruler,
and Guǎn Zhòng
was a worthy assistant,
and yet there were occasions where one takes the wise to be stupid.
How much more in the case of those of us who are inferior to Duke Huán and Guǎn Zhòng.
In Lǔ there was a litigation between a father and his son.
Kāngzǐ said:
"Have them both killed!"
Confucius said:
"It is not quite right to kill them.
For the people do not understand that litigation between father and son has long counted as abominable.
Such behaviour is the fault of the leadership.
If the leadership is possessed of the Way
then such people will not exist."
Kāngzǐ said:
"In governing the people takes filial piety is fundamental.
Now having one person killed in order to severely punish unfilial behaviour
is that not acceptable?"
Confucius said:
"Without having instructed them (for 孝read教) to execute people
that is to cruelly kill the innocent.
When the three armies suffer a great defeat
they must not be executed.
When judicial procedure has not been properly performed
punishments must not be applied.
When the leadership lays things out and instructs and the people submit to begin with
then the people will follow proper custom.
When only after they do not follow one's own example of moral behaviour
and one thereafter deals with the matter through punishment,
then the people will understand the crimes (they are punished for).
Now a six-foot high wall
the people are incapable of jumping over;
but a six hundred foot high mountain
even a little boy can climb up and play on.
This is because the proclivity is slow.
Now it is a long time since the proclivity of kind-heartedness and righteousness has been slow.
Can we say that the people cannot get across the difficulties it presents?
The Ode says:
"Let the people not ."
In ancient times
the true gentlemen guided the people and caused them not to get lost.
That is why their might was immense but it was not applied,
punishments were established but not actually used (because there was no malfeasance by the people)."
So then the litigants heard about this
and they asked to desist from their litigation (between father and son).
Duke Āi of Lǔ consulted Confucius on the matter of administration.
Confucius replied:
"Administration involves causing the people to be rich and long-lived.
Duke Āi said:
"What do you mean?"
Confucius said:
"If one keeps the taxes of all kinds limited then the people will be rich,
if there are no conflicts then one keeps crime at bay,
and if one keeps crime at bay then the people will be long-lived."
The Duke said:
"Ah, but in this way I myself will end up poor!"
Confucius said:
"As the Ode has it:
"Superbly kind is our gentleman
he is the father and mother of the people."
I have never children being rich and their parents being poor."
King Wén asked Lǚ Wàng:
"How is one to run the world?"
He replied:
"The state of true king will enrich the people,
the state run by a hegemon will enrich the gentlemen,
the barely surviving state will enrich the dignitaries,
and the state that has lost the Way will renrich the storehouses:
that is to say the superior kind oozes wealth and the inferior part leaks wealth."
King Wén said:
"Excellent!"
Lǚ Wàng replied:
"Delaying the good is inauspicious."
That very day
King Wén opened his storehouses to support the widowed, the orphaned, and the bereaved.
King Wǔ asked Duke Tài:
"What is the right way to govern a state?"
Duke Tài replied:
"The right way of governing a state
is to take good care of the people, that is all."
The King said:
"But how does one take good care of the people?"
The Duke said:
"Benefit them and do not harm them
perfect them and do not defeat them,
make them live and do not cause them to die,
give to them and do not take from them
give them joy and not bitterness,
be pleased with them and do not get angry at them:
this is the right way of governing a state.
The duty of deploying the people
is to take good care of them, that is all.
When the people lose what they are concerned for
then one is harming them;
when the peasants are unable to their seasonal work
then one is ruining them;
when for those who are guilty one introduces heavy punishments
then one is causing them to die;
when one imposes heavy taxes
then one steals these from the people;
when one imposes corvée labour so as to wear out the people's energies
then one makes them feel bitter;
when one works them too hard and interferes with them
then one causes them to be angry.
So he who is good at running a state
deals with the people like parents taking good care of their children,
like elder brothers taking good care of their younger brothers:
when they hear that the others are hungry or cold they sympathise with them
and when they notice that the others are worn-out and bitter they are grieved on behalf of them.
King Wǔ asked Tàigōng:
"How should a worthy ruler govern his state?"
He replied:
As for the worthy ruler's governing his state
his administration is even,
his officials are not harsh,
his taxes are moderate,
his self-promotion is slight,
he does not, for his own personal good damage official procedure.
Rewards one does not apportion to men without achievements
and punishments he does not dole out to men without crimes.
One does does make rewards on the basis of likes
and one does not order executions on the basis of anger.
Those who harms the people are deemed criminals;
promoters of worthies and whistleblowers are rewarded.
The Inner Quarters are not extravagant
women's special pleas are not followed;
above there is no indulgent secretiveness,
below there are no shadowy harmful plots;
one does not refurbish(新？）the palaces so as to use too many resources,
one does not go on pleasure trips to pavilions and ponds so as to wear out the people (in preparation for these)
one does not make patterned engravings (also on bells?) to please the ear and the eye,
in the public offices there are no worm-eaten hidden treasures,
and in the state there are no homeless and hungry people.
This is how the worthy ruler governs his state."
King Wǔ said:
"Excellent!"
King Wǔ asked Tàigōng:
"If in running the state one often revises laws and ordinances,
what do you think about that?"
Tàigōng said:
"If in running a state one frequently revises laws and ordinances,
one is not taking the law as one's standard,
one is taking what one deems good as one's standard.
And so an ordinance is promulgated and there is unrest.

This is the practice of a true king.

Thus the reason why Lǔ had the practice of a true king

The reason why Qí is not as good as Lǔ

In the Annals it says:
when the four categories of people are equally provided for the Way of the King will flourish and the Hundred Clans will be at ease.

If a ruler desires to bring peace to the world and leave behind him an illustrious name

And it also says:

When an enlightened king deploys his generosity and treats those below him with the appropriate respect
he will show warm concern for those who are distant and reach those who are near.
Now when at court there are no men of worth

And so it is that those who travel on rivers or the seas avail themselves of boats;

Yī Yīn, Lǚ Shàng, Guǎn Yíwú, and Báilǐ Xí
these are the boats and carriages of the leader among kings.
To dismiss one's father or eldest brother, or one's children and grandchildren
is not because one is distancing oneself from them;
to employ one's cook, fishing attendant, enemy or servant

It is that for the maintenance of the altars of state and for the establishment of one's reputation as successful
one cannot but do such things.
It is like the chief carpenter building a palace:

In the time of the Annals
the Son of Heaven was weak
and the feudal lords ran their administrations on the basis of power
and they all revolted and would not come to show their respect at court.
The majority violated the minorities,
the strong ravished the weak;
The southern Yí barbarians and the northern Dí barbarians launched coordinated invasions
and the continued existence of the central states hung on a thin thread.
At that point Duke Huán employed Guǎn Zhòng, Bào Shū, Xiǎn Péng, Bīn Xūwú, Nìng Qī
and thrice preserved a state doomed to ruin
and at one point ensured the continuation of a succession about to be disrupted.
He saved the central states
staved off the Róng and the Dí,
and in the end scared away the Jīng and the Mán
so as to maintain the honour of the house of Zhōu
and to dominate the feudal lords as a hegemon.
Duke Wén of Jìn employed Jiù Fàn, Xiān Zhēn, and Yáng Chùfù,
he strengthened the central states
defeated the powerful Chǔ
brought together the feudal lords,
paid his respects at the court of the Son of Heaven
so as the make the House of Zhōu illustrious.

In Chǔ there was Zǐyù and Déchén

When the state hires worthy men that is auspicious

then good fortune of all kinds will reach his descendants.
This is not how one establishes oneself as a ruler.
A pair of highly qualified people cannot one repeat the other,
a pair of big shots cannot find room for each other,
a pair of power houses cannot join forces,
a pair of distinguished aristocrats find together as equals.
Now when it comes to the matter of repeating, finding room for, joining forces and finding together as equals
they will inevitably involve competing for excellence.
Along these lines the true gentleman will moderate his preferential desires
and in each case he will attend to what is sufficient for him
then it is that he is capable of lasting long.
As for moderating desires and then listening to remonstrations
his respecting the worthy and avoiding impoliteness,
his employing the competent and avoiding treating them as worthless,
when someone acting as a the ruler over others puts into practice these three things,
his state is bound to get stronger and larger and his people will not leave him or scatter (in all directions).
Remaining silent you'll never say the wrong thing
remaining impeccable you'll never do the wrong thing:
a wooden horse is incapable of walking
but there again it wastes no time on food,
an eminent stallion may race along for a thousand leagues per day
but the whips will never get off its back.
Picking apart each thread and counting each grain
is arduous and messy and does not lead to clarity.
And so it that holistic overall consideration of things easily leads to wisdom
and petty cavilling hardly ever leads to wisdom.
When measuring things by the inch
as you get to the zhang you are bound to get things wrong;
when weighing by the gramme
as you get to the dan-measure you are bound to make mistakes:
weighing (those large cases) by the dan and measuring (those long things) by the zhang
is the convenient shortcut and you will make fewer mistakes;
That a fish large enough to swallow entire ships,
when flaundering and thus losing his watery environment,
will be dominated by ant-like creatures
is because he has got separated from his proper habitat;
that any type of monkey, when losing his dendritic habitat,
will get caught by groundbound foxes and the like
is because the non-dendritic environment is not his habitat.
That the flying snake, roaming in the mists, rises up
and the winged dragon, riding on the clouds, rises,
that a macaque, when reaching its tree, thrives
and that fish, when getting to water, frolic about,
all that is because the place they occupy is fitting for them.
When the true gentleman engages in broad study,
his fear is that he might not internalise what he has learnt;
once he has internalised it (what he has studied),
his fear is that he might be incapable of realising it in practice;
once he has become capable of realising it in practice,
his fear is that he might be incapable of showing proper deference in the practice of it.
The true gentleman is not ashamed to study (with others)
and he is not ashamed to consult (anyone else).
Inquisitive consultation
is the basis for proper understanding;
sustained reflection
is the proper way of gaining understanding.
This means that one sets high store by basing oneself on what others know in order to better understand things (oneself),
and one does not prefer using one's own intellect alone to understand things.
As for the Way governing Heaven and Earth:
when things reach an extreme height they revert downwards,
when they become replete they start to leak their content;
all the (five brilliant) colours of things may be splendid enough to blind your eyes
but when their times they will change;
flourishing trees and luxuriant plants,
when the time comes, shed their foliage:
the creatures of this world are exposed to a process of flourishing and decline:
(for) how can they ever manage continue being like themselves.
When the people suffer hardship they become callous,
when they are overworked, fraudulence arises (among them);
when they live in peace they become receptive to teaching,
when they are in a precarious state they start plotting.
If they experience extreme affluence they will start to rebel,
if they are fully content they tend to degenerate;
and thus, the true gentleman refuses to grant both full contentment and extreme affluence.
